## Setup R error handling to go to stderr options(show.error.messages=F, error=function(){cat(geterrmessage(),file=stderr());q("no",1,F)}) loc <- Sys.setlocale("LC_MESSAGES", "en_US.UTF-8")
## Import library library(csaw)
@GRANGES@ tol <- as.numeric("$tol")
#if str($max_width) != '' maxWidth <- as.numeric("$max_width") #else maxWidth <- NULL #end if
#if str($ignore_strand) == 'true' ignore_strand <- T #else ignore_strand <- F #end if
result <- mergeWindows(regions, tol, sign=NULL, max.width=maxWidth, ignore.strand=ignore_strand) ids = result[[1]] write.table(ids, file="$id_output", row.names=FALSE, col.names=FALSE) region <- result[[2]] write.table(region, file="$region_output", quote = FALSE, row.names = FALSE)

param.name: tol
param.label: Maximum distance between adjacent windows
param.help: A value of zero means that the windows must be contiguous whereas negative values specify minimum overlaps

param.name: sign_selector
param.label: Specify a positive log-FC for each window?

param.name: sign
param.label: Positive log-FC for each window
param.help: Upload as datafame with a column of logical values

param.name: max_width
param.label: Maximum size of merged intervals
param.help: Specification prevents the formation of excessively large clusters when many adjacent regions are present. Any cluster that is wider than the max width is split into multiple subclusters of (roughly) equal size. Specifically, the cluster interval is partitioned into the smallest number of equally-sized subintervals where each subinterval is smaller than max width. Windows are then assigned to each subinterval based on the location of the window midpoints. Suggested values range from 2000 to 10000 bp, but no limits are placed on the maximum size if no value entered.

param.name: ignore_strand
param.label: Ignore the strandedness of regions?
param.help: If no is selected, the entries in regions are split into their separate strands.

tool.help: Use a simple single-linkage approach to merge adjacent or overlapping windows into clusters. Windows in regions are merged if the gap between the end of one window and the start of the next is no greater than tol. Adjacent windows can then be chained together to build a cluster of windows across the linear genome.
